transcripts.text: Nowadays, most girls are given jewelry, shoes, maybe a phone or some sort of technology for their 13th birthday.
The door is already unlocked.
But this milestone was different for Jala Shabazz.
I don't know too many people who... had their dad asked, like, give them a house.
Her father, A.V.  Shabazz, gave her a gift that he says could help her in the future, a three-bedroom, two-bathroom home.  His thinking...
Let's put him in a position early at 13, gift her with a house at 13, teach her how to use that house to build onto more houses.
Shabazz says he bought the house for his daughter to help build generational wealth.
You see that?
He says this can be the starting place to help her begin her own financial freedom.

The objective is to be comfortable.  Whatever that means to her is what it means to her.  She determines that, right?  If she's cool with having a house without paying bills and working the job, that's her choice, right?  But if she wants to grow it into a multimillion-dollar empire, that's her choice.
Ajala says she was excited to receive the big gift, but she also admits she was a little scared.
I felt like I was too young, you know?
Like people always say you're too young to do this or do that.  And my dad just gave me a house when I was 13.
She says she instantly thought of all the things that could possibly go wrong.

I'm not very good when it comes to responsibility.  And when I am given responsibility, I suddenly feel anxious and nervous.  Am I going to screw this up?  Is something bad going to happen?  I just think of all the possibilities.

but her dad stepped in to offer some encouragement.  He believes she is ready and responsible enough.  Shabazz is a real estate investor and says Ajala simply needs to do what she's watched him do over the years.

They help me work.  They do the real estate investing.  They do the price quotes.  They put an address to properties.  When we go out, they film.  We assess properties together.  So they're out with me doing the work anyway.
Shabazz says he started teaching his kids about real estate investment two years ago and will buy them all homes when it's time.

I started teaching them that at home, and then that developed into, okay, well, let me really implement this in a real way by gifting each one of my house and letting them take that and move that forward from that point going into the future.
Shabazz says he invested $50,000 into the house.  He considers it a small investment into his daughter's future and the surrounding community.

And there's literally 22 empty houses on this street, right?  22.  So if we own all 22 of these houses and we bring them up to this type of standard, then we control the comps for this area.  Not only that, we boost the comps for the area.  Not only that, we boost the tax intake for the county, which goes to the school system.  So we're building up our own community by buying up the real estate.
Ajala will get some landlord experience as she decided to rent out the home.  And although she may not understand all that her father is doing right now, she knows it's in good faith.
I like the idea of giving your child a house when they turn 13.  I like that idea because it's unique.
Reporting for Atlanta Black Star, I'm Cassandra Burks.
